subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 9th September (vide page 4399), on motion by Mr. poynton-

quote.para: That this Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: .- I regret exceedingly that the Minister in charge of the Bill is absent, because I wish to stress certain phases of the War Service Homes problem which I would like him to hear. In moving the second reading, he told the House that 8,815 soldiers had been provided with homes. The Inter-State Commission, in its report upon rents, said that in the three big eastern capital cities there is a shortage of over 25,000 houses. It is difficult for honorable members to escape the fact that housing is one of the most pressing problems which the people have to face at the present time, at any rate, in the eastern States.
- It is the same in all the States.

- People in my own electorate have approached me with regard to the difficulty they experience in obtaining houses. A house within about 200 yards of the Richmond Town Hall was sold over the heads of the tenants. They had been living in the place for years, and had paid the rent regularly, but the house was sold over their heads.
- No sale can be made that does not respect existing tenancies or sub-contracts.

- Most of the houses in my electorate are held on a weekly tenancy. I do not suppose that 10 per cent. of my electors, save those occupying business premises, have a monthly tenancy. The parents of two returned soldiers for a number of years had been occupying a house in Richmond on a weekly tenancy when they received notice to quit, as there had been a change of ownership. During the mother's absence from home one afternoon the premises were entered and everything thrown into the street. Even the uniforms of the returned soldiers were tossed into the street as if they were rags.
- Can tenants be turned out without notice?

- The owner had obtained an ejectment order, and in such cases, on application to the Court of Petty Sessions, an extension of time for a few weeks is sometimes granted. In another case, the widowed mother of a youth who enlisted as soon as he was eighteen years of age applied to the War Service Homes Commissioner for. a home, and was promised that a house would be built for her as soon as possible. Meantime, the house occupied by her on a weekly tenancy was sold over her head, and, being unable to obtain another cottage, or even suitable rooms, in the neighbourhood, she has had to be content with two rooms at the back of a shop, although there are no conveniences in the shape of bath, copper, or wash troughs. These soldier cases furnish an additional reason why the Department should be speeded up. so that the dependants of returned soldiers may obtain, without delay, the benefits for which the Act provides. There is a great shortage of houses in my electorate, and I believe the position is the same in all the State capitals. The Treasurer told us this afternoon, in the course of his Budget statement, that the population of Australia is gradually increasing. If we had such a tremendous influx of immigrants as some people hope to encourage I do not know how we could possibly house them.

speech.para: I have referred to the treatment which landlords have meted out to parents of returned soldiers. I desire now to mention the experience of an old-age pensioner - a woman who has been in the country for more than sixty years, who has reared a family, and has adult grandchildren. A house occupied by her for some time in Richmond was recently sold over her head, and she was told that she must leave within a week. She searched in vain for another house and while she and her daughter were scouring the neighbourhood her furniture and belongings were thrown into the street. She had no place to go to. and finally had to occupy a condemned house.

talk.start.para: - There has been a great decline in building operations in Australia.

- I admit that, but we certainly have as many houses as we had before the war, and the increase in population is not such as to account for the great shortage. The house now occupied by this old-age pensioner is unfit for human habitation.

- Apart from the obligations of the War Service Homes Commissioner to returned soldiers, the relationship of landlord and tenant is a State matter. At the same time the value of the honorable member's statement cannot be discounted.
- Quite so. On more than one occasion I have referred to the way in which the parents of returned soldiers have been treated by landlords.
- Surely this old-age pensioner's goods and chattels were not thrown into the street before notice had been given her to quit?

- An ejectment order had been obtained. Persons who are as bitterly opposed to me politically as is the honorable member, have taken up the case of the returned soldiers to whom I have referred. They have written to the local press complaining of the inhuman conduct of various landlords. I was asked only yesterday by a returned soldier whether the moratorium still applied, and if it was permissible for a landlord to increase his rent. He told me that three months ago his rent was raised by1s. 6d. per week, and that a further increase of1s. 6d. per week had just been made. I informed him that the Crown Law authorities advised that the moratorium did not apply to him after his discharge.
- There is no power to put out a tenant without an ejectment order.

- Application is made in all these cases for an ejectment order, and if the tenants do not ask for an extension of time, ejectment immediately follows. As a rule, the poorer a person is the less he knows of law and business. The InterState Commission, in a report on rents which was published in 1919, showed that in 1918 there was a shortage of 9,000 houses in Melbourne and suburbs, and of 12,000 houses in the metropolis of Sydney, or a total shortage of 25,000 houses in respect of all the State capitals.

speech.para: The Minister, in introducing this Bill, pointed out that provision was made for increasing from £700 to£800 the maximum amount which may be advanced for a "War Service home. Roughly speaking, that is an increase of 13 per cent. ; but since there has been a far greater increase in the prices of building materials, while the price of land in many districts has also gone up, returned soldiers in this regard will be no better off than before.

talk.start.para: - It will not be possible to build these homes for £700.

- I do not think it will be. The £800, of course is intended to cover the cost of the land and building. In company with the honorable member for Parkes (Mr. Marr), the honorable member for Wide Bay (Mr. Corser), and others, I recently inspected a number of War Service homes in course of erection at Canterbury and Bell, as well as in other suburban districts. We were greatly impressed with the class of work being carried out, and found that it compared most favorably with the work of contractors in the neighbourhood. I believe that the War Service Homes Commissioner is doing a magnificent work. The Minister stated that the Commissioner had been hampered in his operations by the excessive prices charged for building material by rings and combines. There is a difference of opinion amongst honorable members as to the action taken by the Government in purchasing saw-mills and timber areas in Queensland. That action was taken because of the exactions of the Combine. The Government might well have secured an option over these mills and timber areas, and then have consulted Parliament as to the contemplated purchase, just as they have done in regard to the advance of £550,000 to the Westralian Farmers Limited for the erection of silos. The War Service Homes Commissioner should be freed from the operations of rings and combines, particularly when they continue to increase their prices. As the honorable member for Dampier (Mr. Gregory) put it, those who are putting up their prices to returned soldiers are thieves, swindlers, and scoundrels. They profess to be patriotic, while at the same time they are robbing the men who fought for them by making exorbitant charges. As the result of the Queensland purchases, the Commissioner will be able to obtain timber much cheaper than before. The cost of a soldier's home, with the land, is now £800, as against £700 previously but it is the soldier who has to pay the extra £100.
- Does not the Commissioner claim that he is able to build homes at a cost of under £700 ?
-He says he is able to build them more cheaply than a private contractor can.
- He is buying his timber more cheaply.

- That is so. There is a difference of opinion upon the matter of the purchase of saw-mills and. timber areas in Queensland. It is not claimed that the vendors put a pistol at the head of the Government and said that, unless the purchase money was put up straightway, the Commonwealth could not get these mills or timber lands, and as Parliament was in session at the time the representatives of the people ought to have been taken into the confidence of the Government as to what they proposed to do. I am an advocate of Government enterprise as against private enterprise, and, although, as the Minister has pointed out, the Government can carry out work more cheaply than private enterprise can, I still maintain that Parliament ought to have been consulted in this matter. I do not know what action honorable members in the Country party propose to take.
- As a matter of practical business, would the owners of these mills and properties have given ah option which would be open to debate in this House?
- The arrangement could have been made subject to the approval of Parliament.
- Is not that the same as giving an option?

- On other occasions contracts have been entered into by the Government subject to the approval of Parliament. However, I want to give credit where it is due. Under the War Service Homes insurance scheme, 2,059 certificates have been issued; the gross amount of insurance covered being £2,135,000. On the 30th June of this year, the revenue from premiums amounted to £3,115 3s. 6d., an amount of £1 19s. had been paid in adjustment of claims, and £103 18s. had been absorbed in administrative expenses, leaving a balance of £3,009 3s. 6d. to the credit of the fund. Administrative expenses represented only 3.4 per cent. Under this scheme, for a £600 house of brick, stone, or cement, the insurance premium is 7s., as against 13s. charged by a private company. For a wooden house of an equal value the premium is 19s., whereas a private company would charge 40s., or over 100 per cent. more. As I am an advocate of the Government undertaking this class of business, I take this opportunity of putting on record a table of the premiums charged under the Queensland Government insurance scheme, which, I understand, was established by the honorable member for West Sydney (Mr. Ryan) when he was Premier of the northern State. The Federal Public Service Journal, of the 31st July, contains the following: -

quote.para: The Journal of the Queensland State Insurance Office has published an interesting list, giving concrete examples of savings effected in the cost of fire insurances by the establishment of the office. The results are most pleasing, for they mean, not only that every one insuring with the Government is deriving the benefit of its policy, but that a consequential advantage is accruing to those' who insure with private companies, which, of course, have had to reduce their premiums in order to retain business. The list is as under.

As the private companies are expected to make dividends for their shareholders, it will be obvious that the interests of the average citizen are far better served by placing his risks where he will derive the full benefit of all profits - that is, with the State Insurance Office.

speech.para: These figures show throughout that, as a result of this Government enterprise, there has been a reduction in the premiums charged by private insurance companies of from 25 to 50 per cent.

talk.start.para: - But the State Government impose another penalty.

- Probably the honorable member is an advocate of private enterprise, whose premiums are, as the figures I have given demonstrate, from 25 per cent. to 100 per cent. more than is charged under a Government scheme.
- Do not get annoyed.

- Last week the honorable member had an opportunity of voting with his 'Government for Government enterprise in relation to saw-mills, and he did so. My object is to place on record figures which show the advantage of such undertakings as against private enterprise.
- But does not the honorable member wish them to be accurate?
- Does the honorable member say that these figures are not accurate?

speech.para: Mr.Corser. -They do not go far enough. There is an imposition over and above the premiums mentioned in the table.

talk.start.para: - The honorable member will have an opportunity of pointing out where they are inaccurate. The Queensland Government have commenced a general insurance business, and have not only done the work cheaply, but have also compelled private companies to reduce their rates to a figure lower than is to be found in any other State. That the insurance companies are making enormous profits at the expense of the general community is proved by the fact that the premium under theWar Service Homes scheme for a £600 wooden house is only 19s., as compared with £2 charged by private insurance companies. The Government are on the right lines in this regard.
- The Government are always on the right lines when they adopt a plank out of our platform.
- That is so. The Labour party has been advocating Government insurance for years.
- The State is using its own instrumentalities to protect its own property, but is not out to do other people's business.

- I would launch out and do other people's business. The Minister for Repatriation (Senator Millen) has told us that the War Service Homes Commissioner has been hampered by combines - timber, brick, and cement -and any one who has read the report of the Inter-State Commission on such combines will readily see how these have operated to increase the cost of building. The Commission has pointed out that in 1914 the labour engaged in the erection of a brick cottage of five rooms, including a bathroom and a kitchen, cost £131 6s., as against £146 3s. in 1918, the increase being under £15, or not quite 11 per cent., whereas the cost of material in 1914 was £278 17s., as against £410 18s. in 1918. Seeing that the total increase of labour and material was 50 per cent., it is obvious that the employers got 35 per cent. The report of the Inter-State Commission continues to point out the effect which the inauguration of the New South Wales State Brick Works had in keeping down the price of bricks -

quote.para: The Manager of the State Brickworks gave evidence, and produced the Auditor-General's reports on the workings of this enterprise. The works sell common bricks at 38s. 6d. per 1,000, as against the Combine price of 50s. per 1,000. The works price in 1914 was 35s. The maximum output in any one year has been 38,000,000, the output in 1917 (a strike year) was 28,000,000, the estimated output for 1918 was 42,000,000. The present capacity for output is 44,000,000, but there is room to double the works.

A total sum of £87,669 has been advanced by the Government, of which £20,000 has been repaid out of profits. Operations began in 1911, and the financial results, according to the Auditor-General's report, 1918, have been remarkable. He states - "Accumulated profits at 30th June, 1918, were £23,622 8s. 9d., or 26.94 per cent.; reserve for renewals, £27,489 15s. 6d., or 31.36 per cent., amounting in all to £51,112 4s. 3d., or 58.30 per cent. of the capital employed."

speech.para: If the State Government works could bring about such results, with bricks being sold at 38s. 6d. per 1,000, what must have been the profits of the people in the Combine, who were getting 50s. per 1,000? These are the men against whom the War Service Homes Commissioner makes his bitter complaints. This is the type of their patriotism. They lose no opportunity to charge enormous prices for the material which they sell for the building of soldiers' homes. The Inter-State Commissioners proceed further to quote the Auditor-General, as follows : - " In addition to the declared profits, direct savings to the extent of £08,470 18s. 2d. on account of Government services must be taken into consideration. These savings were effected by buying from the undertaking at prices below those quoted by outside manufacturers, and not only Government services, but also the general public, participated in these reduced prices, though necessarily such estimates are not included. It will thus be seen that the profits were £23,622 8s. 9d., plus the savings of £68,470 18s. 2d., or, in all, £92,093 6s. lid., a sum in excess of the capital employed, viz., £87,669, by which amount the State has benefited."
To that the Commissioners comment -

quote.para: The percentages quoted above are on the loan capital,' viz., £87,669, ignoring the reduction by £20,000, and exclusive of accumulated profits.

speech.para: They then go on to prove what the Brick Combine has done in Melbourne. Their report says -

quote.para: Nearly the whole of the brickmasters within the Melbourne metropolitan area are associated in a very close combination, which takes the somewhat unusual form of a proprietary company.

Formed as the instrument of a Combine, the company was registered in 1896 with a nominal capital of £100, only £7 of which was paid up. The company form, the memorandum, and articles were, indeed, rather of the nature of a screen behind which, by means of an agreement between all the members of the company, its real purposes could be effected. By that original agreement, each member leased his works to the company. The leasing appears to have been purely nominal, the real object being, as above stated, to create a Fool. In 1904, a fresh agreement was made, and there have been modifications since that time, but the essential character of the organization has never been changed.

As the method followed required all payments for bricks supplied to customers to be made either by the customers themselves or by the constituent companies to the central company, the latter was always in funds, and always in- the position of owing moneys to its members. The members refrained from withdrawing the whole of the amounts to which they, were entitled, and thus built-up a reserve within the company, which, within a few years after its formation, began to be used for the acquisition of brick and tile properties. Between the date of formation ( 1896 ) and the year 1904, four such properties in various suburbs had been acquired. These properties are hold by the company under lease at a total annual rental of £1,855, but they are not being used for the production of bricks or tiles, the evident intention being to restrict competition.

In 1908 the sum of £19,993 was placed in the books to the credit of capital account (originally £7), making £20,000. At that time, the articles did not authorize the company to increase its capital, nor was it till December, 1912, that the articles were amended to confer such authorization. So far as the filing of particulars with the Registrar of Companies was concerned, no action was taken even then. Further, in 1913, the directors decided to increase the capital to £50,000, in 50,000 shares of £1 each, and to increase the issued capital to £26,000.

speech.para: Next the Commissioners point out that the people in this Association make the stipulation that, unless customers secure the whole of their requirements from the Association, they will get nothing at all. These men in the Melbourne Brick Association are the people whom the War Service Homes Commissioner has to fight to-day, and from whom I hope to see him very shortly freed. It is an absolute disgrace that there should be citizens of Australia who posed during the war as ardent patriots, but who are now fleecing returned soldiers by Charging exorbitant prices for material necessary to build soldiers' homes.
I received a letter a few days ago dealing with the increase of the maximum grant for home building. The writer says -

quote.para: On making inquiries at the War Service Homes to-day, I was informed that the amount was not to be retrospective. Might I point out the injustice this will do to many of us who are in the throes of having our homes, erected, and bargained on - an increased advance. I had to pay cash £155, in addition to the £700 advance, to get even a moderate home. At this time, the Minister for Repatriation said the advance was to be increased to £800. On this I allowed a few desired improvements to be done; expecting to obtain an additional advance. This was backed up by inquiries then made at the War Service Homes Department. A man who is having his home constructed now needs just as badly the £800 as the man who is yet to have his house built.

speech.para: That is the position, and I sincerely hope the Government will consider it carefully and sympathetically. If the extended grant is to be applied only to those homes which will have been erected after the passing of the Act, great and unwarranted hardship will be suffered by returned men who entered into arrangements prior to its introduction.

talk.start.para: - I do not think that that will be the position.

- This returned man, whom I have quoted, has been informed by the Department that the promised increase will not be retrospective. The building of soldiers' homes falls under four categories to-day. There is the type of home which the Commissioner constructs. Then there is the home built, for example, by the South Australian Government independent of the War Service Homes Department; there is the home erected by the Commonwealth Bank; and, lastly, there is the home purchased by a returned man himself, in regard to which he has secured an advance from the Department.

speech.para: I have received another letter from the Limbless and Maimed Soldiers Association of New South Wales, as follows : -

quote.para: The press here states that the War Service Homes Bill is before the House; therefore, it is evident that the position of limbless and maimed soldiers should have immediate attention. Feeling assured that all members recognise the just claims of the limbless and maimed soldiers, we are writing to ask for your assistance on our behalf on the floor of House. Briefly, provision for old age in respect of housing should be made in the following way: - Men who have had two legs and an arm amputated, or who otherwise have had more than two amputations, should be given a house to the full amount provided under the War Service Homes Bill. Just fancy a man with, no legs and having but one arm having to take rent out of the paltry allowance he now receives! In Sydney, the boys sweeping the streets get, when twenty-one years of age, £4 3s. per week. Yet a man who has had two legs and an arm amputated while fighting for his country can only get £4 per week under the latest Act. For double amputations, we ask half the cost of a house. For amputation of leg or amputation of arm, one-third the cost of a house. For the loss of sight of one eye, one-fourth the cost of a house.

speech.para: I recently introduced a deputation to the Assistant Minister for Defence (Sir Granville Ryrie) on behalf of a number of limbless men. I know that if the Assistant Minister were free to settle their troubles the arrangements made would be in every way satisfactory, for he is a man with a large heart, and is very sympathetic towards the returned soldier.

talk.start.para: - When the House adjourned for dinner, I was dealing with the position of limbless men. Recently it was my privilege to introduce a deputation to the Assistant Minister for Defence (Sir Granville Ryrie), with a view to obtaining adequate pensions in such cases. With the deputation were Mr. Slater, M.L.A., of Victoria, Mr. and Mrs. Evans, who were in charge of the Anzac Buffet in London, and two or three other ladies, whose names, I regret to say, I forget, but who went to England at their own expense, and devoted themselves to the welfare of the soldiers. Those ladies, to whom every credit is due, are now again in Australia, and are now centering their efforts on behalf of soldiers who suffer from double amputations. Some days ago, I asked the Assistant Minister for Defence a question as to what provision was made for such sufferers, and he gave me the following information: -

quote.para: Double Arm Amputations. - As far as the records of this branch show, there is only one such case in this State (Victoria). A special pension of £8 per fortnight is being paid, as it is considered that it would be impossible to train this man in any trade.

Double Leg Amputations below the Knee. - This class is not considered to be totally and permanently incapacitated. A full pension of £4 4s.per fortnight is paid, and, if considered medically fit for it, vocational training is provided.
Double Leg Amputations above the Knee. - At present this class receives £4 4s. per fortnight (full pension). The Commission is now considering what form of repatriation would best suit these men.

speech.para: The lot of these men ought to be made as easy as possible, and I am sure that the Assistant Minister will agree with me that £2 2s. a week is not sufficient for men with double amputations below the knee. There is, I believe, one man in the State of Victoria, who has his two arms and is in possession of all his mental faculties, but, owing to a double amputation above the knee, he has to take a taxi cab to his work, and be carried from the kerb into the building. I know that this Bill deals only with housing, but I refer to the matter just in order to convey to the Government that there is a general desire that these men should be treated in the most considerate manner. I have received, in common, I suppose, with other honorable members, the following communication from the President of the Limbless and Maimed Soldiers Association, conveying the opinions of that body as to the improvements desired in the arrangements for pensions and housing : -

quote.para: As newspapers state the War Service Homes Bill will be brought up in the Federal Parliament in a few days, it would be well for this matter to have speedy attention.

We have in our association two members - Mr. W. Lockyer, of Leichhardt, and Mr. A. B. Turner, of Rozelle - who have each had two legs and an arm amputated. These men should be given a home of their own.

speech.para: I indorse that, because I believe that these men should at least have a home of their own.

Mr. Lockyer's mother and wife told our association that at present Lockyer and his wife have one room at his mother's residence. To get about from room to room he rolls along the floor, as invalid-chairs are too big to get through the doorways. This shows the necessity of building a house to suit such terrible cases. The house need not be big, but the doors could be made wider, and other little conveniences introduced to make their lot, at any rate, a little easier than it is now.

Provision already exists under the Bill, I understand, to provide for a man totally and permanently incapacitated; but we have been informed that a ruling has been given from Melbourne that such provision is only to apply to blind men. It should be extended to men such as Lockyer and Turner and other deserving cases.

Double amputations (amputation of two legs or amputation of an arm and a leg, or amputation- of an ar.m and loss of sight of .one eye, or amputation of a leg and loss of sight of one eye). - While we do not ask for the whole cost of a house to be provided, it is reasonable to ask that they be given, say, half the cost of a house, " the cost of a house " to be regarded as the full amount provided for under the War Service Homes Act. If the Government did this, with the aid of patriotic bodies and individuals, friends and lodgers, the men would bo able to raise the 'balance themselves, although it might take some years to do so.

Leg amputation or arm amputation. - One-third of the amount allowed under the War Service Homes Act for building a home; that is to say, one-third of £700, . or whatever amount might be "fixed if the £700 is altered.
This Bill proposes to alter the amount to £S00-

These men are having great difficulty in getting suitable work, and as they advance in years, their earning capacity will become less. It is, therefore, most desirable that they should have a house of their own for their old age. By making the concession asked for the Government would be finding one-third of the cost of the house, and the men would have to find the remaining two-thirds.

Loss of sight of one eye. - These men are not affected in their earning capacity to the same extent as the other badly disabled, although there are individual cases, such as where a man w'as a blacksmith - he is unable to follow that occupation on account of flying sparks. We suggest that where a returned soldier has lost the sight of one eye, the Federal Government grant one-fourth of the full amount allowed under the War Service Homes Act; that is, one-fourth of £700, or whatever the amount might be.
It should be remembered that a man -who has only one eye runs a big risk of becoming totally blind.

It was my privilege, as one of the first things I did in this Parliament, to secure that Braille and Moon writing should be taken through the post free of charge; indeed, I am as proud of that as of any action I have taken in this Parliament. We should certainly look after the blind, for there is no affliction so awful as loss of sight.

An alternative proposal -has been put forward in the case of men who have had a leg amputated, or an arm amputated, or who have lost the sight of an eye, should the Government not agree to the foregoing, then they should certainly encourage the men to become owners of their own houses by advancing them the full amount under the War Service Homes Act free of interest for five years.

In putting forward these recommendations, it is pointed out that they are the result of deliberations of the whole of the men affected. The Limbless and Maimed Soldiers Association has a membership of over 000 in New South Wales, which is practically all the men in the State who can join under its rules. Meetings are held fortnightly at which various problems are fully discussed, while the committee have gone into all phases affecting disabled members, and the recommendations in the foregoing are the consensus of opinion of what would be fair to the men, and would not be asking too much of the Federal Government.

There is a very strong association also in Western Australia, while a similar organization has recently been formed in South Australia, and arrangements are being made for similar action to be taken in the other States. You will see that the proposals are based entirely on the principle that no help will be forthcoming from the Federal Government except where the men are willing to help themselves. It will be an encouragement to the men to secure houses, if the Federal Government shows that it -is willing to help those who are prepared to help, themselves.

talk.start.para: - A very moderate statement.

- It is, indeed. That letter comes from Sydney, but similar cases have been brought under my notice in Victoria, and also cases known as T.B.; or tubercular. Unfortunately, the tubercular cases have been transferred .from Mont Park to the Austin Hospital for Incurables. The honorable member for Kooyong (Sir Robert Best) will remember that some time ago I referred to a man suffering from tuberculosis, who had been turned out of the Austin Hospital, in order to make room for cases from Mont Park. I have only to add now that that unfortunate man died about a month ago.
- Why were they removed from Mont Park ?

- In order that they might be housed at the Austin Hospital, and it would be difficult to find a more depressing place to send them. We ought to try to brighten the lives of such unfortunates, and not make their circumstances such as to render them despondent.

speech.para: There are one or two other phases of the Bill to which I should like to refer. I am pleased to note, from paragraphs c and d of clause 2, that munition workers, war workers, and representatives of the Young Men's Christian Association are brought within the operation of the Bill, and will have the option of purchasing homes under the improved conditions. Personally, I think that the Home Service men who were engaged in transport work should also have their claims considered. Clause 3 provides that where any proposed expenditure is over £5,000, it shall be submitted by the Commissioner for the approval of the Minister. Last Friday, it was suggested here that all expenditure over £5,000 should be referred to Parliament itself. I am as bitterly opposed as any one to the combines, trusts, and rings, which are compelling the returned soldiers to pay extra prices for building material, for it is the soldiers who have to pay in the long run. There is a class of people who think that the Government is " fair game," but, in this matter, they are not "taking down" the Government, but the soldiers, and I hope that Parliament will devise some means of dealing with them. Where by the marriage of a widow of a deceased returned soldier with another returned soldier, each possesses a War Service Home, it is not right that two houses should be retained, but they ought to have the value of the house at the time the Government takes it over; and the clause, dealing with this matter is, in my opinion, a very fair one. I believe that good work has been done in the past in the provision of War Service Homes, and that this Bill will do something further to improve the lot of those limbless men to whom I referred, and to the returned soldiers as a body.

talk.start.para: .- I in- . dorse many of the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Tudor), and I think the House will unanimously agree as to the necessity for the amendments proposed by the Bill. It is generally conceded, I think, that the increase of the amount to be advanced to soldiers for the purchase of homes from £700 to £800 is necessary in these times, when the cost of building material is so high. I ask leave to continue my remarks.
