talk.start.para: .- In perusing the speech of the Minister for Repatriation (Senator Milieu) in another place, I notice that8,213 applications had been approved out of 18,000 submitted. I admit that there is a great difficulty in getting houses built, but there has been some unfair delay in the Department in taking over houses already built for which applications have been submitted. I have heard it stated that the Department has not sufficient valuators. There are plenty of valuators in Australia, and if that is the difficulty, it can be overcome. I have been informed of men who have been waiting as long as nine months for the Department to take over mortgages on houses which they have contracted to buy. The Bill, as originally submitted to another place, provided that the applicant should deposit 15 per. cent. of the value of the house to be built or purchased by the Department. I am pleased that, at the instance of Senator Poll, that provision was knocked out. It would be a hardship for the applicant, particularly if he be a married man with a large family, to have to find 15 per cent. of the amount for which he is applying.

speech.para: It has come to my notice that young fellows who were under military age when they enlisted have been, debarred from the benefits of this Act. I think they should be included in these benefits, notwithstanding that they deceived the Department by incorrectly stating their ages on their enlistment papers. They passed all the tests, and proved themselves men and soldiers, and they should be entitled to all the benefits which are conferred upon their comrades.

talk.start.para: - How are they penalized ?

- They are excluded from the repatriation benefits; they are deprived of their leave, they are ineligible to get the advantages of the War Service Homes Act, and they are not entitled to the war gratuity.
- The Government are taking advantage of their youth.

- They are. A serious defect in the War Service Homes Act is the disability placed upon war widows. It is very hard in these times of high cost of living for a woman, particularly if she has three or four children, to be able to find a 10 per cent. deposit on a home. In the case of a war widow, or widowed mother, that condition should be waived; it should be possible for every such woman to become possessed of a home at the reasonable prices at which houses are being provided by the Department.

speech.para: Underthe parent Act, it is not possible for the wife of a soldier who returned to Australia mentally afflicted to submit an application for a home. I notice with pleasure that this Bill amends the Act so that the wife in those circumstances may submit an application.

This Bill brings under the provisions of the Act war workers and munition workers. I have known applications by war workers and munition workers to be refused by the Department because the applicants had not gone abroad under the Government scheme. As honorable members know, long before the Government propounded a scheme for sending war and munition workers to England, a number of men had already departed, paying their own fares. They worked in Great Britain throughout the war, but, on their return to Australia, they found themselves excluded from the benefits of the War Service Homes Act

talk.start.para: - They are not included by this Bill.

- The war workers are; but only those who went to England under theægis of the Government. We ought to include those who paid their own fares. I know of one man who paid his own fare to England, and while there suffered a paralytic stroke. He returned to' Australia, but his wife and four children are debarred from any benefit, even under the Pensions Act, because his affliction occurred in England. I think the House will agree that the wife and family of men who went abroad at their own expense to do war work should not be penalized.
- If the public could be consulted, they would not object to those women getting all the benefits.

- It is an unfortunate fact that some of the rulings by the Departments are in opposition to the views expressed in this House. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Tudor) mentioned instances of that kind to-night. I personally understood that, under the Repatriation Act, a man who lost two legs, ox one arm, was regarded as totally incapacitated, and entitled to a full pension, which I thought was to be £4 4s. per week.
- Cannot we do something for the young fellows who enlisted when they were just under age, and fought for three or four years? Is it not a shame to debar them from all benefits ?

- The Department returned some of those young fellows to Australia when they found they were under age, but others were kept at the Front throughout the war. Thus the Department condoned the offence; and I think the young fellows should be entitled to the same "benefits as other soldiers. I mentioned last night the case of a young man who enlisted when he was sixteen years of age; in appearance, he might have been nineteen years of age. In France, the authorities discovered that he was under age, and returned him to England, where, however, he was kept on hospital duties for nearly two years. Notwithstanding that, he is deprived of the benefits conferred on other Australian soldiers.
- On what » ground- is he refused ?
- It is considered that he deceived the Department.
- The view taken by the Department is that such men were not eligible for service, and, therefore, are not eligible for benefits. Those who were found out were returned to Australia.

- The War Service Homes Act is being administered in much the same spirit as is the Repatriation Act. Many Australians who were in England when the war broke out enlisted with King Edward's Horse or some other Imperial unit, and, in my opinion, they, being Australians, and not able to return to Australia to enlist, should have been allowed to join up with the Australian Imperial Force on the other side.
- And those who had a little social influence could do so.

- Had that policy been permitted, the Australian Imperial Force units would have been strengthened when they badly needed strengthening during the stress of the 1918-19 campaign. Those men who were compelled to enlist in Imperial units because they were not allowed to join the Australian Imperial Force should benefit under the War Service Homes Act and the Repatriation Act, and I hope that the Government will agree to include them in the benefits bestowed upon other Australian soldiers).

speech.para: Every honorable member will agree with the Leader of the Opposition that the insurance scheme is a good idea. It will save the soldiers many pounds per annum on the insurance of their homes. I do not agree with the honorable member that the insurance * companies are robbing the public. We must remember that the Department can insure the houses at a cheap rate, as it has not to provide special offices, employ a special staff, and send valuators all over the country, as the companies do. While the companies no doubt are making a very fair profit, I do not think they are making the 100 per cent, to which the Leader of the Opposition referred.

Another commendable feature of the Bill is the endeavour to prevent trafficking in these homes. Trafficking has been taking place. Some soldiers who had acquired houses at £700 have been approached by members of the public with offers of £800 cash.. They have taken the cash, wiped out their indebtedness to the Department, and pocketed the profit of £100. That practice defeats, the object of the Act, which was not to permit speculation, but to provide homes, for soldiers at a reasonable price. Of course, when a soldier having acquired a home in one district sets a position in another locality, it is necessary for him to sell out. This Bill provides that the Department may take back the home at the purchase price, plus the value of the improvements which the owner has made. Having regard to the prices at which the houses are supplied and the easy terms of repayment, the Government are making a vary fair proposition. A home thus returning to the possession of the Department becomes available for another returned soldier.

talk.start.para: - Do they not, give the soldier the privilege of selling direct to another soldier?

- No. The returned soldier who buys one of these homes to-day will not be able to dispose of it for at least five years. This provision will protect the soldier against himself. I believe that in the event of a returned soldier being transferred to another State or to another district, the Commissioners, as reasonable. men, would be prepared to take over the home they had built for him, and to provide him with another in the district to which he had been transferred. Under the regulation which requires that a deposit of 10 per cent, shall accompany every application for a home, many of the men are being deprived of the benefits of the Act. The Commissioner naturally desires some security for the money which he advances on behalf of the Government, and he says to an applicant, " You must be prepared to put down a cash deposit of £70 with your application for the building of a house worth £700." There are, however, many men who cannot find such a deposit, and where they are able to satisfy the Commissioner that they are in steady employment and receiving a certain wage, they should be given the opportunity to secure a home for themselves. There are hundreds of men who have been waiting for the proposed increase of the maximum advance from £700 to £800. A house consisting of three rooms and a kitchen is of practically little use to a man with a wife and four or five children. This Bill, increasing as it does the maximum advance from £700 to £800, will enable the Commissioner to build slightly larger homes. I understand, however, that an applicant will have to satisfy the Commissioner that the increased maximum is absolutely essential to secure a house suitable for his requirements. Where a man can put down a substantial deposit the Commissioner will doubtless raise no objection, but the maximum of £800 is not to be secured as a matter of right.

speech.para: The Minister for Repatriation, when speaking in another place, stated that up to date the average cost per home was £647. That amount includes the cost of the land. With a number of other honorable members I recently inspected some of the War Service Homes at Canterbury, Bell, and other districts in the neighbourhood of this city, and was greatly impressed by the splendid character of the work being put into them. Quite recently I had the honour of opening sixteen of these War Service Homes in my own electorate. They had been erected at a cost of £640 each, and the mayor of the municipality, a builder with thirty-five years' experience, declared that he would not accept a contract for the erection of such houses for an additional £100 per house.

talk.start.para: - They were built by day labour.

- That is so. The Commissioner is building on a large scale, and in that way is able to effect savings. I agree that the Department should not be allowed to expend any sum exceeding £5,000 without the approval of Parliament. I am satisfied that honorable members would not hesitate to sanction any greater expenditure where it could be justified, and I hope that in future all proposals for substantial expenditures will be submitted to this House. At the same time I believe that the bargain which has been made for the purchase of saw-mills and timber areas in Queensland is a good one, and will reduce the cost of these homes to our returned men.
- At what price is the timber to be supplied for the erection of these cottages - at the price at which it is valued in the report submitted to the House in regard to the purchase of these areas ?

- I cannot say how the price paid will work out per 100 super. feet. Round timber in a forest might be growing, or it might have been felled. Now that we have these mills and timber areas we should be able to obtain timber for the erection of cottages for less than we have hitherto had to pay.

speech.para: As I stated last night, there are something like 1,000,000 bricks, as well as huge stacks of timber lying at Canberra, and I think this material could be put to good use in connexion with our vocational training scheme. I was pleased to hear the Minister state that there were already a few returned soldiers settled at Canberra. We are asked sometimes, "What can Canberra produce ?" May I say that it grew the first merino wool raised in Australia? It has grown some of the best wool, wheat, and fruit produced in the Commonwealth ; and what has been done in the past can be repeated in the future.

Some of the large unions in the big cities of Australia will not allow more than a certain number of returned soldiers to secure vocational training in the various trades. In this regard the unions of Western Australia have set a splendid example. Without desiring to detract from the good work done by the other States, I must say that Western Australia did nobly throughout the war. When the Repatriation Department started its vocational training system there, representatives of the unions waited on the Deputy Comptroller and said, "Are you prepared to allow your trainees to join our union?" The Deputy Comptroller replied that he could see no objection to the proposal, whereupon the unions made an offer to themselves provide vocational training for returned soldiers. They said, " We will train these nien for you." And to-day they are training a number of them in various trades. It would redound to the credit of trade unions in other States if they would follow that .example. In New South Wales, however, the bricklayers have declined to allow more than 100 returned soldiers to receive training in that trade. That is a foolish policy.

talk.start.para: - Has not a trade a right to protection?

- The trade does not need to be protected to that extent. The demand for buildings is so great that we shall not be able to cope with it for many years. If the trade unions generally would train, our returned men as the unions in Western Australia are training them, the community, through the Repatriation Department, would be saved an expenditure of many thousands of pounds. The Commonwealth Parliament has absolute control over the Federal Territory, and steps should be taken to use the supplies of building material there in affording returned soldiers vocational training. Instead of paying 60 per cent, of the wages of many of these men, and asking, their employers in the city to pay the remaining 40 per cent., we could send them to Canberra, and the money now being spent in providing for their training in the large centres of population could be devoted to the erection of the administrative and other buildings there. Our returned soldiers would thus be afforded an opportunity to secure training in various trades, while, at the same time, we could get full value for our money.
- Does the Bill relate to Canberra, or to War Service Homes?

- In view of the statement made to-day by the Treasurer (Sir Joseph Cook) as to the resumption of work at Canberra, I hope that we shall soon have the honorable member and other representatives of Victoria agreeing with us that it is time that the Federal Parliament had a home of its own. Every honorable member has the interests of Australia at heart. We may differ on many subjects, but out of such differences of opinion much good may arise. I do not think that we shall ever create in the hearts of the people a truly

speech.para: Australian sentiment until the Government of the Commonwealth is removed from the influence of all our large cities. I have nothing against Melbourne. Although I am a Sydney native, I do not hesitate to say that the influence of Sydney on the Federal Parliament would probably be worse than that of Melbourne, and I repeat that we shall never inculcate in the minds of the people a truly Australian sentiment, until the Commonwealth Parliament has a home of its own.

I hope that the Cabinet will make provision, not only for the war workers who went Home under Government supervision, but for those who went away at their own expense and, in some cases, also paid the travelling expenses" of their wives. All these should be brought within the scope of this Bill.. We are now providing for officers of the Young Men's Christian Association who went overseas, and these men should also be given the full benefits of this measure.

talk.start.para: .- I am in accord with most of the amendments of the principal Act for which this Bill provides. In common with other honorable members, I fully appreciate some of the difficulties with which the Commissioner has had to contend, and realize that in some respects he has done very good work. According to the speech made by the Minister for Repatriation (Senator Millen), when introducing this Bill in another place, the Department has built a number of homes at a very reasonable price. I am delighted that it has seen fit to give the principle of day labour a trial. The Minister stated that the Commissioner's price for labour only, in the erection of cottages at Yarraville, was £175 each, whilst the lowest price for labour by contract was £190 each. A saving of £15 in respect of each home was thus effected. In the case of homes at Heidelberg, the Commissioner's estimate for labour cost was £292, as against the lowest contract price of £364, so that by resorting to day labour the Department was able, in respect of labour alone, to save £72 on every home erected in that district. If the Commissioner had received fair treatment at the hands of outside traders he would have been able to do much better for our returned soldiers. Unfortunately, we have in this community certain people who seek to make a profit out of the building of homes for our returned men. They have taken advantage of the necessities of the Commissioner, and have enormously increased* the price of every article required by him. Startling statements were made by the Minister as to enormous increases in the price of various commodities since the Commissioner commenced his work. Exceptional steps have been necessary to overcome the difficulty. I wish the Minister every success. I have no time for those " stay-at-homes " who, while boasting of their patriotism and describing others as disloyalists, show their patriotism by making it almost impossible for those who risked their lives for the safety of the Empire to secure a home for themselves in their own country. We cannot, of course, indorse the action of the Commissioner in purchasing saw-mills and timber areas without first consulting Parliament; 'but I entirely agree with the principle. With the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Tudor), I say that an option over these properties should first have been secured and the proposed purchase submitted to Parliament.
- The Commissioner secured an. option over these properties for one month.
- Then the proposal to purchase them should have been submitted to Parliament within that time.

speech.para: No one will describe the Minister for Repatriation as a Labourite, but when speaking in another place recently, he bitterly denounced the profiteers who seek to profit by the necessities of our returned soldiers. He called attention to the fact that when he desires to purchase a block of land for soldiers' homes, these people will ask three times more than its value for land taxation purposes. That shows some of . the difficulties which face the Commissioner. I do not know what progress has been made with the building of soldiers' homes in cities, but practically nothing is being done in country districts. In fact, I do not know of a single 'house that has been built in the western part of Victoria, and it is almost impossible to get. the Department to move, at all in the purchase of a house already "built. The honorable member for Parkes (Mr. Marr) is of opinion that this lack of action is due to the fact that there; is- an insufficient number of valuers; but I know that in

Ballarat, where there are homes for sale, months elapse before the Department can move in the matter. A month ago I submitted a case fo the Commissioner, but nothing was done until at last the soldier, who had built up a tidy little business, found that the home he wished to purchase was sold over his head. Upon making inquiries, I found that the War Service Homes work in country districts was done by the Commonwealth Bank, and that, although the Bank had been negotiating for the property in question, it had nothing in writing to show that it held an option. I hope that this branch of repatriation work will be speeded up, and that the work of valuing houses submitted for purchase will be undertaken promptly, so that decisions may be arrived at without unnecessary delay. It should not take more than a month to ascertain whether a property under offer is worth the money asked by the vendor, and to complete the purchase.

talk.start.para: - I am afraid that I have had the same experience in endeavouring to get the Department to hurry.

- The Honorary Minister knows some of the difficulties confronting honorable members in dealing with these cases. The Minister for Home and Territories (Mr. Poynton), who represents the Minister for Repatriation in this House, is an old miner; and lives in a mining district, and ought to be acquainted with the point which I am about to mention. I do not know too well the conditions in other States, but I know those which apply to mining townships in Victoria. In the early days of mining in this State, if a man wished to build a home for himself brat had not sufficient money to purchase the necessary land, all he had to do was to pay 2s. 6d. for a miner's right,, which entitled him, not only to mine, but also to hold a block of land on which to build a house. He was only asked to renew his miner's right each year by an annual payment of 2s. 6d. ; but his title to his land was as good as a Crown grant. He could go to a money-lender and borrow upon his home. There are 6,000 houses in Ballarat built on these residence areas, but the War Service Homes Commissioner will not consent to the purchase of a house built on a residence area. He will only consent to the purchase of houses built on freeholds. The great difficulty is that, not only does it take six months to convert a residence area into a freehold, but it costs the occupier at least £60 or £70 to do so. The Victorian Lands Act provides that before a residence area can be converted in this way, it must be submitted to auction, and the difference between the assessed value of the improvements on the area and the full amount realized on the sale of the house and the land goes to the State Government. That is to say, if the occupier purchases his own property in this way, it costs him at least £60 or £70, this figure representing the unimproved value of the land itself. To overcome the difficulty, I intend to move in Committee to insert a new clause giving the Commissioner power to advance money for the purchase of homes built on residence areas. When private money lenders are willing to advance on these titles, they must be quite good enough for advances to be made on them by the War Service Homes Commissioner. As a matter of fact, there is no more valid title in the world.
- There ought to be no insuperable difficulty in getting the State Government to pass a small measure agreeing to the conversion of these holdings.

- Before I had a temporary spell away from this House, I frequently interviewed the Minister for Repatriation, asking him to consult with the Minister for Lands in Victoria in order to see if some arrangement could not be arrived at in this direction, but evidently nothing has been done, and many hundreds of men in Ballarat who went to the war are denied the opportunity of getting a home for themselves on their native land.

speech.para: I sincerely hope that the Honorary Minister has listened with a favorable ear to the remarks of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Tudor) in regard to double amputation cases.

talk.start.para: - I have asked for specific cases on which to consult the Minister in the morning.

- We may differ politically at times, and Honorable members opposite may call us disloyalists, or employ other harsh terms in regard to us, and although some of us may have thought that the war ought to have been ended by negotiation, while others may have thought that it ought to have been fought out to the bitter end, we are nearly all Australians, and recognise that we owe a debt to those who went overseas to fight for us. But our debt to those who came back in good health is as nothing when compared with what we owe to those unfortunates who returned minus both legs, or even one leg. These men ought not to have to struggle for a living. The Leader of the Opposition has read a letter stating that one man who has lost two legs and one arm is living with his wife in one room in his another's house, and because an invalid chair cannot be pushed through the door he is obliged to roll through it every time he wants to get out of the cottage. Surely we ought not to allow that sort of thing to continue in Australia. We talk of giving these men a pension of £4 a week. If they had not gone away they would have been earning more, and this man would have had his legs and his arm. He is denied many enjoyments. He cannot accompany his wife down the street on a Friday or Saturday. He cannot go to races, or football matches, or pictures. In fact, he is a prisoner for life. The least this Parliament can do is to see that he never has the landlord knocking at the door asking for his rent. Homes ought to be provided for such men, and their wives, and little children. There ought to be no hesitancy about doing it, and it surprises me that years after the war has ended these men are still obliged to live in miserable circumstances, and are still asked to pay a big deposit and so much a week to get a home, just the same as men who came back in the enjoyment of good health. I hope that before the Bill leaves this Chamber a new clause will be inserted making provision for such cases.

speech.para: I do not see the necessity for the deposit of 10 per cent. it practically means that if a soldier is unemployed he cannot get a home. He is obliged to show that he has some capital or is in work. At any rate, even if a man is. earning £3 or £4 a week, it is a very heavy strain on him to have to put by £50 or £70 to pay as a deposit for. the building or purchase of a home. Most of these soldiers are poorer to-day than when they went to the war. It may be said that they can put up their gratuity bonds; but, as one who has had more to do with returned' soldiers than most honorable members, I know that the majority of married returned soldiers are only too glad to have their bonds to purchase furniture. Most of the men are pretty "hard up" to-day. However, when we read the Minister's statement as to how the soldiers are repaying the Department, we see that we have very little to fear on their part. Just as they were " great " abroad they are going to be " great " at home. The Minister informs us that the amount due by soldiers on 30th June last was £116,144, and that all but £2,247 had been repaid, and that £2,247 is by no means a bad debt, because most of it will most likely be paid. In the face of these figures what valid reason can the Minister have in insisting upon a deposit of 10 per cent.?

talk.start.para: - Is the 10 per cent, on the full £800 or merely on the last £100 ?
- I understand that it is on the last £100.
- I thought that that provision had been wiped out.

- I have not seen where that is so, but I trust it is the case. With the honorable member for Parkes I sincerely hope that those who went away from Australia to Great Britain as war workers or munition workers before the Government scheme was initiated will be included in the benefits of this Bill, and also those Australians who were in England when war broke out and enlisted for service in the British forces. Any Australian who was in England at that time could have got his passage back to Australia, enlisted here, and thus received the benefit of the increased pay of the Australian Imperial Force, and would now be entitled to all the benefits of our pension and repatriation schemes, but those who paid no regard to getting increased pay, and whose only object was to get over to France or Gallipoli promptly enlisted in the British Army, and now that they have come back to their native country they find that they are debarred from participating in the benefits given by the War Service Homes Act.

speech.para: I hope that we shall be able to come to some agreement about the utilization of trainees in the building of these homes. The Minister has mentioned that he has had some difficulty with the leaders of the trade unions in regard to vocational trainees, but I cannot conceive that there should be any trouble in this respect, because there will be any amount of scope in this country for carpenters and brick layers. The training that vocational trainees are getting in some directions is not of the character that will turn out competent tradesmen. In the Ballarat School of Mines there are large classes where trainees are instructed. The plastering class plasters a wall and then tears it down, and does the same again next day. The bricklayers build a chimney or a wall and pull it down again. Half the time they are dismantling what they have built, and cleaning up the bricks which they have been using. It is the same with the painters at their jobs; for one-half of their time they are undoing what they have just completed. Honorable members opposite cannot tell me that trade unionists are not just as anxious as any one else to see that our returned soldier trainees shall have every opportunity to learn a trade and earn their living by it. Why should they be put to this useless game of building up and pulling down again? In Ballarat, the Defence Department has a big block of land. What is to prevent the construction of thirty or forty homes on that area by utilizing the labour of these trainees ? There is no need to go to Canberra to build homes which will not be wanted for very many years. Let them be built where the people live, where homes are needed. We want the trainees to be turned out as competent tradesmen ; and I am satisfied that if there is any difficulty with trade unionists - which I doubt - the trouble could be overcome, and these young men put to permanent jobs in which they would have their hearts, rather than that they should be wasting half their time undoing what they have done. I hope that the Minister (Mr. Rodgers) will note the suggestions offered, and will make this measure better, broader, and more practical than it is at present. The Government should endeavour to meet the wants of all who took any part whatsoever in the great war. Whether they were soldiers, or Young Men's Christian Association men, or war workers in any department, all should have the opportunity to participate in the benefits of our post-war legislation.

talk.start.para: -4~l. - T nm in accord with the statements of the honorable member for

speech.para: Yarra (Mr. Tudor). I was astounded to learn that those lads of eighteen and under, who fought for and who saved Australia, are now debarred from enjoying the privileges which are available to their older comrades of the battlefield. It is a matter which surely requires explanation. "We should not be satisfied with such Ministerial statements and suppositions as have so far been offered. I cannot believe that war gratuity bonds are being withheld from these soldier youths;, indeed, I have been told that some, at any rate, have received their bonds. We were glad enough to get boys of eighteen to go to the Front. When they were sent into the firing line they were not debarred on account of their youth. Our soldiers, young and old, were not required to pay any deposit. To-day, however, such disabilities are set up when it comes to a matter of their receiving the benefits of Australia's soldier legislation. The hesitation and the refusal to give adequate sustenance to men who have lost legs and arms in the protection and salvation of their country is appalling; and members of this Parliament would be weak indeed if they did not insist upon some definite statement or assurance from the Government to-night. What have these maimed and limbless men ahead of them? As the honorable member for Ballarat (Mr. McGrath) says, their wounds and amputations have made them practically prisoners for life. We would not be worth our salt if we did not insist upon some improvement in their lot. I give the Minister (Mr. Rodgers) every credit for desiring to do the very best possible for returned soldiers. Honorable members know his sentiments, for was he not the first amongst us to enter with enthusiasm, and much individuality, into the cause of repatriation? At least, we may expect sympathy and generosity from him. Surely the Minister has sufficient power to -say that some improvement shall be brought about.- Let the Minister signalize his introduction to the front bench in the happy manner which I now suggest. I am quite sure that the Assistant Minister for Defence (Sir Granville Ryrie) would not hesitate to do his utmost to sweep aside all departmental disabilities ; for did he not have under his command in Egypt and Palestine some of these youths of eighteen and less? The honorable member for Ballarat pleaded that the Government should set vocational trainees to work to build homes upon land owned by the Defence Department in Ballarat. The honorable member sought to cast a slur upon Canberra. Does he know everything about Canberra? Does he know that the Government own thousands of acres of land there, and that 1,000,000 bricks are lying idle, not to mention some £50,000 worth of timber ? Why not send the vocational trainees to Canberra to build homes where they are bound to be required within a very brief time?

I am given to understand that the matter of the Queensland timber deals is to be revived this evening. I sincerely hope that such: will not be the case. This is not the time to re-open a discussion of that matter. We are now establishing the case for better treatment of our returned men. I was very much interested in the speech of the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Tudor) ; his remarks were to the point. He cited specific cases and invited the Minister concerned to go straight to his officers and secure particulars regarding the actual position in which our maimed and limbless men find themselves to-day. " Let him learn exactly what pensions they are drawing ' ' - pleaded the honorable member ; ' let him ascertain what sort of a miserable bread-and-butter existence they are being compelled to lead because the Government and Parliament are not doing their duty." These unfortunate men, who were maimed in our cause, have little enough to look forward to for the rest of their lives. Who will say that their lot should not be made as cheerful as possible?

As for the matter of refusing the gratuity to youngsters, I have not the language at my command to adequately condemn such a thing. Neither can I fitly describe my feelings in that, before they can get homes for themselves, we should require a 10 per cent, deposit from returned soldiers. There were neither Labour nor 'National, nor Corner party politics in the ranks of the Australian Imperial Force, and we should not allow party feeling to step in to their detriment now. Why should we ask poor men, who can ill-afford - if at all - to raise a 10 per cent, deposit, to find any money whatever before being helped to secure a home? We did not place any 10 per cent: limitation upon their desire to go to Egypt and France.

Then there should be some better method adopted in regard to the valuation of properties. Honorable members are not the best judges of such matters; men of practical experience should be called into the service. The building of War Service Homes is a new and a huge project, and when honorable members realize the extent of operations up to the present, they must admit that, so far, the Government have done fairly well.

talk.start.para: - I remind the honorable member that this amending Bill proposes both to increase the number of beneficiaries and to extend the specific benefaction.
- Will it be provided that boys who enlisted under eighteen years of age will receive the same consideration as other soldiers?
- I promise the honorable member that his suggestion will be very carefully considered.

- That is no good; we shall insist on something more than " consideration." We know that the Minister is in sympathy with the request I make, and will try to do something to have it granted, and I am prepared to accept what he says. Will the Minister promise that those men with double amputations, referred to by the honorable member for Yarra (Mr. Tudor), will receive generous consideration?
- I promise the honorable member, and all other honorable members who have made specific suggestions, that I shall lay them before the Minister for Repatriation, and with him will go fully into them.
- Will the Minister promise that in regard to those cases he will make some alteration?

- I cannot personally promise that, but I can promise that I will go into the matter carefully with the Minister for Repatriation, and will make certain recommendations. Those recommendations will come up in the usual way for confirmation, or otherwise.
- Will the Minister promise that men who are unable to pay a deposit, hut who have a decent record, will be brought into the scheme and get houses?
- No deposit is required from any applicant under the main Act.

- I am satisfied the Minister will go into the matter carefully, but it is no good his promising what he will do. personally; we require a Minister who says he will do a thing, and does it. However, 1 know the Minister's heart is with us, and I shall take his word.

.- I have much pleasure in supporting the request made by several honorable members that youths who enlisted under the age of eighteen shall receive the same consideration as is given to their older comrades. I also suggest that special consideration should be given to those maimed men who are in receipt of a fairly decent pension, and desire to secure homes of their own. The Commissioner builds homes only in cases where there is a fair probability of repayment, but the pensions of the maimed men are secured as long as they live, and the recipients are really in a better position to keep up their payments than many engaged in outside occupations ; and I trust the Minister will see his way clear to accede to the unanimous wish of the House in this regard.

speech.para: I am very pleased to see 'that a clause is being inserted to carry out a promise, made both here and in .another place when the original Act was being' passed, in regard to large purchases. I think, however, that something more than this clause is necessary to guard this country from engaging in State industrial undertakings when there is no suggestion whatever that any further power is given than to make contracts. The constitutional aspect of the question has been laboured sufficiently, and I shall not labour it further. This House decided last Friday, by a majority of only two, when four honorable members who were against them were away, that it was in favour of the procedure that had been adopted by the Government; and I only regret that those (members have not yet returned so as to enable us to reverse that decision. In no speech during the discussion of the principal Act was any suggestion made that the Government should undertake saw-milling enterprises. Provision was made for the purchase of land for building of houses, and power given to enter into certain contracts, but nothing further. It was said last week that, a sugar purchase contract had been made, but no suggestion was ever made that the Commonwealth should undertake the milling of sugar. These, however, are not the grounds on which I object to the proceedings of the Commissioner, nor on which I wish some additional power given to Parliament to enable it more effectually to control his actions and movements. Experience of past Government transactions leads us to the conclusion that, by the action that has been taken, not merely will the output of mill timber be lessened, but additional charges will be placed on the soldiers for the building of their homes, and they will get less value for their money. I have had an intimate connexion with the timber trade, and can claim to speak with some experience. The whole history of the Australian timber trade is scarred with the ghostly spectres of big timber companies which have failed. These were companies promoted by private enterprise, and, in other respects than in connexion with timber, eminently successful. In my own electorate there was the British-Australasian Timber Company, a subsidiary company of Dalgety's, which was capitalized at something like £250,000. Its property was in probably the best hardwood timber country in Australia, but in five years the bulk of that capital was lost. The same thing may be said of companies in Tasmania and in Victoria. The profits of which the Minister for Repatriation spoke are not made in connexion with the supply of timber, but in connexion with certain trading profits. There are big companies which have been successful such as the Allen Taylor Company and Ellis Brothers, in New South Wales.

talk.start.para: - They are a perfect Combine !

- They may be. I am personally familiar with the country in which these companies operate, and I have never travelled in the northeast district without seeing representatives of the firm giving personal supervision to the saw-milling enterprise. All experience in this trade shows that if any but those personally interested in the success of the venture is given any control, the result is loss and disaster. Every countryman knows the tricks of the timber trade, and I suppose there is no trade that lends itself so readily to roguery. So familiar is this fact that the tricks are regarded much in the same way as an ordinary man regards any device to keep his return of taxable income down to the lowest possible amount. All sorts of dodges are resorted to in order to apparently increase the amount of timber supplied, and to make an inferior class of wood look like a superior class. When this sort of thing takes place in the case of big private companies, is it to be wondered at that every Government timber enterprise results in failure? There have been such enterprises in New South Wales, Queensland, and Western Australia; and in the case of Queensland, in 1916-17, where. I think, something like £60,000 in capital had been sunk, £9,000 had been lost up to -that date. The cause of this loss was stated by the Auditor-General to be, in the first place, due to the fact that for about eighteen months those in charge had 'been selling pine at 18s. 4d., when it cost 24s. 6d. to produce.
- What about the profits on the State mills?

- There have been no profits on the State mills in Queensland up to the present. Then, again, we are told that, for two years, hardwood had been sold at something like 2s. less than the actual cost of production. In the face of these facts, we cannot wonder that the Auditor-General makes certain comments on the conduct of the Queensland State timber enterprises in the last report available. He says -

quote.para: No insurances have been effected so far as the branch mills are concerned. In my opinion, this is a matter in which the enterprise is taking more than a fair margin of risk. . . .

The absence of a profit and loss account in connexion with this store was commented upon by the inspector who examined the accounts, and arrangements have now been made for this to be kept at the head office of the sawmills in Brisbane. . .

On the 3rd January, 1918. the then general manager of the State Saw-mills estimated the cost of purchase, transfer, and re-erection of a mill from Gootchie to Liverpool Creek, and providing extra plant, &c, would be £3,100; and, acting on this estimate, approval was given, on 9th February, 1918, for the erection of the mill. . . .
The construction is not yet completed, and the cost is already 98.45 per cent, higher than the estimate. . .

The present general manager explained that the excessive cost is due to the fact that the person to whom the rebuilding of the mill was intrusted died before the erection was well under way; and, as there were no plans available, the work was handicapped through no one being acquainted with the details of the mill as it previously existed. The great distance from head office prevented close supervision, and consequently increased the cost of construction.

talk.start.para: - What year does that refer to!

- The year 1919. The year does not matter, because no matter what Government was in power there was a regular loss. Those figures ought to convince honorable members in regard to the sawmilling transactions in Queensland. This undertaking that has been so lightly taken in hand by the Minister and the Commissioner is a good deal further from Melbourne than the mills referred to in the report I have quoted were from Brisbane.
- Is the honorable member objecting that too much was paid for the mills ?

- I shall deal with that aspect in a few moments. These mills are not likely to result in avery great saving to the soldiers, who have to pay for the homes, but in extra cost. The Treasurer stated on Friday that the public have to pay for the houses. The payers are not the public, but the soldier purchasers, and if the cost of construction is excessive, those men are being robbed all the time. The experience in New South Wales is equally as interesting as that in Queensland. According to the Auditor-General's report, there is a- State timber yard, and the capital involved is £177,000. In four years, the Government have lost 75 per cent, of the capital. Making a special effort last year, they doubled the business of the timber yard, but they doubled also the losses, which amounted to £68,000. The Government were running also joinery works similar to those which are to be part of the scheme into which the Commonwealth Government have entered in Queensland. After three years the New South Wales Government Joinery Works went out* of commission, and the Auditor-General has written " off an amount of £29,000 as a dead loss. In addition, the

speech.para: Government of that State a few years ago entered into a proposition on all fours with that which the Commonwealth Government have undertaken in Queensland. It bought a timber mill and land near Gloucester, reputed to carry millions of feet of timber. A member of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly was unseated over the "transaction. These richly endowed areas of timber were to have afforded good cutting for years and years. The Government built a railway siding for 6 or 7 miles into the forest, and three years ago, where there was supposed to be boundless timber for which a high price had been paid, the position was such that the Auditor-General explained the losses or small profits on that particular saw-mill as being due to the fact that all the timber cut there had to be brought by rail 70 or 80 miles. Thus this mill, which was supposed to be in the centre of the forest, was at a disadvantage in comparison with every private mill in the State. Evidently, the New South Wales Government bought the wrong property. The Commonwealth Government may have done a similar thing in Queensland. At any rate, they have probably paid a good deal more for the property than they should have paid. For these reasons that Government timber enterprises fail, even if the Commonwealth transaction were a good one from a commercial point of view as an actual deal, I would still oppose the policy.

I come now to the merits of the transaction itself. Five dr six months ago the Country party submitted, in connexion with the Repatriation Bill, a proposal for co-operation on the part of returned soldiers. Each member of this party stressed the point that the only profitable class of saw-mill was that conducted personally by the men interested in it. We suggested that the Government should advance £2 for every £1 provided by the soldiers, so that co-operative mills might be established. That was a fair basis for co-operation in connexion with timber sawmills. The proposition was laughed at.

talk.start.para: - Members of the Labour party supported the proposal solidly.

- It was laughed at by Government supporters, and, in another place, was regarded as an absolutely wild cat scheme. Certain sections of the press ridiculed it altogether, and said that it would involve the Government in an expenditure of an enormous sum of money. Only after a great deal of pressure were we able to secure the adoption of a £1 for £1 scheme, and the provision of £500,000, nearly all of which was applied for in behalf of projects for the establishment of woollen mills. The quantity of timber that is to be turned out by these precious mills which the Government have purchased is no more than could have been produced by five hardwood mills and six softwood or pine mills which could have been erected for £2,500 each. For a total expenditure of £27,500 for saw-mills, of which the Government would have been asked to advance only £18,000, the whole of the output that will be obtained from the contract made in Queensland could have been obtained from soldiers' co-operative mills. We brought forward a proposition that is already in operation in the electorate of Richmond, where 3,000 acres of land was made available by the Manifold Brothers for returned soldiers. They erected their own mills, and are able to cut timber at a profit, and build houses much cheaper than the price at which the Government are proposing to provide homes under this Bill. The Government have committed themselves to the expenditure of approximately £500,000 to obtain the same quantity of timber as could have been obtained from soldier co-operators for an expenditure of £18,000.
- Where was the timber to come from ?
- Within 50 miles of the honorable member's own electorate I could show him four times as much timber as there is on the whole of the properties which the Government have acquired.
- Adjoining a railway?
- Absolutely on the railway. It is a good pine forest, and a Queensland Government mill is already established there.
- Is the area pre-empted ?

- The only authority that has anything to do with the area is the Queensland Government. The Treasurer stated that the main reason why the contract was entered into was that the Government could not procure a supply of timber at reasonable prices for the erection of War Service Homes. In the papers which have been laid upon the table, it is plainly stated that Messrs. Lahey and Brett were willing to sell the whole of their output to the Minister for Repatriation for the erection of War Service Homes at a discount on the market price. Does any honorable member believe that with the ordinary lack of supervision, which is inevitable in a Governmentcontrolled saw-milling business, the Commissioner will get more timber out of the mills than Messrs. Lahey and Brett, who have been working the mills for years, could have supplied ?

- Did they offer to supply the whole of the timber from the mills at a fixed price, or was the price to be on a sliding scale, and to vary according to the prices fixed each fortnight by the saw-millers in combination ?

- The honorable member may be surprised to know that the contract suggested to be undertaken by the Commissioner with Mr. Brett is on a sliding scale, and the price will automatically rise and fall with the variations of the market. As to whether any other timber is available, I have previously pointed out that the Federal Government has provided £40,000,000 or £50,000,000 for soldier land settlement by the State Governments, and I have complained repeatedly that the Commonwealth is handing over this immense sum of money without having any control over the expenditure. The Queensland Government, which is repatriating soldiers very successfully, received £17,000,000 from the Commonwealth for this purpose. Do honorable members think that the State Government, which is receiving that amount from the Commonwealth for repatriation purposes, should be allowed to hold on to the timber it has all over Queensland, and not allow the Commonwealth to have it for the War Service Homes scheme, instead of it being used for ordinary private purposes. Both the Queensland and New South Wales Governments have enormous stocks of standing pine in their own forests at Brooloo,Dorigo, and Upper Clarence, and is it fair that the Commonwealth, after making huge sums available for those States, should be committed to the expenditure of £500,000 bearing interest at, I suppose, 6 per cent. when the timber that is to be acquired through this expenditure could be obtained from those Governments and paid for as used? I may here add that in the profits estimated by Mr. Barton, the interest on the capital is not taken into account.
- Did the Commonwealth approach the Queensland Government?

- I do not know. I heard it rumoured, but I do not vouch for the statement, that the Lahey proposition was offered to the Queensland Government a year or so ago at a considerably lower figure. There is supposed to be 90,000,000 feet of pine in these areas. In the Brooloo scrub, where a mill has been erected by the Queensland Government, there is from 200,000,000 to 300,000,000 feet of pine very much closer to a railway than is the bulk of the timber bought by the Commissioner.
- How far is it from the seaboard ?
- About sixty miles from the seaboard, and 130 miles from Brisbane.
- What would the royalty be?

- I shall deal with that in a few minutes. The points which I am submitting to the House are worthy of consideration. Any transaction of this kind, which is being carried out by the Minister and the Commissioner without the sanction of the Parliament, should be kept absolutely free of suspicion.

speech.para: What is the position? Dealing with Lahey's property we find that it was first offered to the Commissioner on the 23rd February last. One month's option was given in April, and was extended with very little difficulty, so that there is no reason why the contract should not have been submitted for the approval of this House. It took six months to complete it. In the second place we find that the price at which the property was originally offered was made up of some £191,000 for the standing timber and £46,000 for machinery. If the Commissioner had gone to the Queensland Government, and had said, " Give us the right to use your timber," he would have done better even if he had been called upon to pay a bigger royalty than is demanded in respect of the timber acquired, which is by no means small.

talk.start.para: - The State saw mills could not get all they required.

- The Government saw-mills can obtain more than they require because their .timber areas are closed entirely to all private saw mills. In connexion with this transaction £460,000 will have been paid already, and will be bearing interest. Fully one-half of the timber acquired will not be handled for at least five years, and, during the whole of that time, we shall have to pay interest on the purchase money. It would have been better to have made an arrangement with the Queensland Government, even if a bigger royalty had been demanded. I see no reason why the Queensland Government should not have met the Commonwealth in a reasonable spirit, since this timber was required for the building of War Service Homes.
- Were they asked to meet the Commonwealth in this matter ?

- I should like to have some' information on that point. Had such an arrangement been made we would have had no interest bill to meet except in respect to the amount actually paid each year by way of royalty. As matters stand, in respect of interest on the purchase money, a considerable sum will have to be charged against the timber used in the construction of these homes. The Lahey property was found to consist of various blocks. It was examined by Mr. McDaniel, of the Yarraman Timber Company, who valued some of the timber up against the tram lines at 12s. per 100 superficial feet, and that 2 miles from a tram line at 10s. 6d. per 100 superficial feet. Some of the timber he found to be 14 or 15 miles distant from a train, line, and in view of the difficulty in getting it out, since rough roads would have to be traversed and a creek crossed sixteen times, he valued it at only 4s. per 100 superficial feet. He said, further, that the scrub timber, which bulks largely in all the valuations, was not of much value at present owing to the high cost of transport, and that the hardwood was so scattered and in such small quantities that it would not pay any company to consider it in the slightest degree.
- For whom did he make this report?
- For the Commissioner. Strange to say, as to the machinery acquired from Lahey's Limited, the only man in Queensland who could be found to value it was the other vendor, Mr. J. F. Brett.
- There is no man in Queensland who knows more about timber than does Mr. Brett.

- Quite so. I am not imputing motives. The only point that I wish to make is that in connexion with a purchase of this magnitude - a purchase concluded without the sanction or knowledge of Parliament - it is essential that the whole proceedings should be above suspicion.
- Has the honorable member any doubts as to the genuineness of the transaction?
- I shall deal with that matter later on.
- An important letter is missing from the file.
- The timber purchased from Messrs. Lahey has been valued at something like 8s. 9d. per 100 super. feet standing taking the average over all.
- When Mr. Brett inspected Lahey 's property, was his own property under offer?

- Yes, both properties were under offer. I come now to the statements which have been made as to the enormous amount of money that the Government is going to make out of these transactions. According to Mr. Barton, the accountant who made an examination on behalf of the Minister, if all the timber estimated to be on these holdings can be taken out and finished for ordinary building purposes, the deal, taking the prices ruling when the estimate was made, will show a profit of £2,300,000. That, however, is on the assumption that the prices then ruling - prices that were largely inflated owing to the difficulty of obtaining shipments of Baltic - will be maintained over a period of ten years. An estimate was also obtained as to what it would cost to convert the timber into ordinary finished building material. A Mr. Reynolds Driver, of whom I have no personal knowledge, submitted two alternative schemes. The first of these was that he should buy the timber at 9s. per 100 super, feet all round, and that he should cut it and sell it to the Commissioner at a certain price.

speech.para: He estimated that under such an arrangement extending over a period of ten years, the Commissioner would have to pay him £1,900,000, or, if he were paid simply so much per 100 feet to cut the timber, it would cost the Commissioner £1,738,000. In estimating the profit of £500,000 or £600,000 that was to ensue from such a transaction, the pine tops, Mr. Barton says, have been valued at 5s. per 100. We now learn that Mr. Brett has been given all the pine tops on his property, as well as those on the property of Laheys Limited, and that Mr. Lahey values the pine tops on his property at 1s. 6d. per 100. Questions had been asked and answered by Mr. Barton as to the status of Mr. Driver, who suggests that the transaction will result in a huge profit. We learn that, unfortunately, Mr. Driver's financial position is not strong enough to enable him to take on such a proposition, but that, if the Commissioner is prepared to assist him, he will run the whole business as a personal venture. Mr. Barton reported that Mr. Driver could not undertake the contract without Government assistance, and he suggests that he could get outside assistance, but by methods which he feels sure would be unacceptable to the Government. Mr. Brett was willing to take on the work of preparing the timber for building purposes at a much higher rate than that proposed by Mr. Driver. His rates were to go up if the cost of production increased. He said nothing about any reduction in rates as the cost of production decreased; but, if a rise in the cost of production took place, there was to be a proportionate increase in rates.

One may well imagine how such an arrangement would operate. We know the system on which saw-millers work. Mr. Driver, if his scheme were accepted, might carry it on for a couple of years. During that time he would have cut out the timber worth 12s. 6d. per 100 superficial feet, for which he would be paying only 9s. per 100 superficial feet, and would thus make a handsome profit. But by the time he got to the timber valued at 4s. per 100 super., he would probably say, " I have had enough of this," and leave that timber on the Government's hands.
This, then, is the sort of proposition that has been carried through. At the close of the negotiations a joinery business was also purchased.

talk.start.para: - Will the honorable member tell us what was the proposition as accepted)

- From what I can gather, Mr. Driver's proposition was recommended ; but no definite action has been taken with regard to it, . The whole scheme is still in the air. It is a question whether the Government should run its own saw-mills after the methods that have been adopted in Queensland and New South Wales, or whether they should accept Mr. Driver's offer.
- But have not the Government purchased these properties!

- I understand that the Government say that it would be impossible to get out of the bargain without a very serious risk of repudiation. Mr. 'Barton, the accountant who was employed to inquire into this matter, says that he thinks it fair comment to state that experience shows that Governmentowned ventures cannot be run as economically as those owned by individuals. For that reason he suggests that one of the propositions made by Mr. Driver should be accepted. The Government have purchased a " pig in a bag." Wo have purchased these properties at the top market prices.
- Did I hear the honorable member say that an important document was missing from the file?

- I would not say that; but I do say that, from information I have received, the file is not quite complete. Had a certain document been on it, I would have been able, po far as the other timber proposition is concerned, to make a statement which I am unwilling to make unless the actual document is before me.
- To what letter does the honorable member refer?
- A letter to the Minister dealing with the report, and the question of the valuation of Brett's property.
- By whom was that letter written!

- I do not feel at liberty, at this stage, to mention the name of the writer; but I intend to put on tha notice-paper a question in relation to the matter. The position is that the Government have bought on the basis of the very high prices ruling for timber in April or May last. I am convinced that no timber man in this country thinks for one moment that such prices will be maintained during the next ten years. There can be no doubt that the value of the scrub wood, especially that on Mr. Lahey's property, will be less as other timber comes into this country with the fall in shipping freights.
- What is the price to which the honorable member refers?
-Over 50s. per 100 super, feet.
- The current price in, Brisbane to-day is 69s. per 100 super, feet.
- That price will not rule very long. The Federal Government has paid the price of sawn timber.
- It is going up every week.

- Prices will, probably continue to increase for some little time. We have bought for ten years ahead. The accountant states that the profit of £500,000 or £600,000, which is the difference between Mr. Driver's estimate and the market price at the time of the purchase, takes no account of interest for ten years on the £500,000 spent on the purchase. Estimated at 6 per cent., this interest would amount to roughly £30,000 a year, or £300,000 for the whole period of ten years, so reducing the estimated profit by that amount. '

speech.para: I am satisfied from the experience of Government timber enterprises in Western Australia, New South Wales, and Queensland, that there will be a considerable loss on the transaction, which' apparently is to be borne by the soldiers, who are to have the doubtful privilege of having their outside furnishings made of colonial pine instead of American redwood, because the former is 45s. per hundred cheaper. The Government would be well advised to get Lahey or Brett to handle the proposition, even at ti cost of £60,000 or £100,000 if they desire the output maintained.

talk.start.para: - -Does the honorable member think that they could be induced to take it back?

- Not being a lawyer, I would not care to give a legal opinion on that point, but my opinion is that, having made the purchase, we must try to make the best of the bargain, and endeavour to induce Mr. Lahey, or Mr. Brett, or both of them, to run this business on a commission basis, to enable the output to be kept up, because I am satisfied it will not be maintained under Government control. I would like to see provision in the Bill stipulating that no proposition of this magnitude shall be entered into under any circumstances without opportunity being given to Parliament to say whether it approves of the policy entailed or the actual contract itself.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Mr. Watkins) adjourned.
House adjourned at 10.5 p.m.
